**CRIME FICTION**

FALL 2022/ Monday 1530-1820

Professor Goodwin [profgood@ntnu.edu.tw](mailto:profgood@ntnu.edu.tw)

Among the most popular sub-genres of fiction are detective and mystery novels, with plots that uncover answers to pressing questions: Who did it? Who committed the crime, and why? In this course we analyze the long-term appeal of this sub-genre in its historical, sociological, cultural and literary contexts. We cover the historical and critical development of detective fiction as it began to emerge in the mid-nineteenth century in America (Poe) and England (Conan Doyle and Wilkie Collins), to the development of the figure of the private detective (Sherlock Holmes, Agatha Christie’s Poirot and Miss Marple, in the Golden Age of detective fiction in Britain (the “cozy” whodunits and puzzlers). In America, the sub-genre detours into hardboiled and noir crime thrillers, fiction featuring female detectives, police procedurals, courtroom thrillers, “ethnic” detective series and the advent of the psychopathic serial killer. In investigating the narrative structures of detective fiction, we consider the significance of its various sources: the Gothic novel and penny dreadfuls/dimestore novels, among other sources. The course also introduces contemporary critical and theoretical arguments concerning popular fiction and genre studies, to enable advanced students to develop a sophisticated understanding of these texts and their cultural contexts, and of the conventions of the genre itself and subgenres, with some examples of these texts in other media such as film and television series. Although our focus is on British and American crime fiction, in their presentations students may also focus on international crime writers (for example, Japanese).

REQUIREMENTS:

As the success of this course depends on student preparation and participation, students should read the assigned texts in advance and come to class ready to participate.

**GRADING POLICY:**

Grades will be based on Attendance and Participation; a Report (on a crime writer of your choice; check with instructor first); a Midterm and Final take-home essay.
